;;Elon Musk。
;

;Elon Musk 将于本周在 Bletchley Park 参加 Rishi Sunak 的人工智能安全峰会，政府消息人士证实，两人将于周四在这位亿万富翁的社交媒体网站 X 上进行现场对话。

;

;这位科技亿万富翁将成为为期两天的峰会中最引人注目的与会者之一由总理主持，讨论先进人工智能的危险。

;

;马斯克的出席将提升这次峰会的形象，而许多世界领导人已决定不参加此次峰会。

;

; >;唐宁街坚称苏纳克并未受到其他世界领导人的冷落，尽管预计很少有人出席。

;

;No 10 表示政府对苏纳克今年早些时候宣布的峰会邀请的反应感到满意今年，试图让英国走在国际人工智能监管的最前沿。

;

;但首相的国际同行中相对较少的人可能会加入其中，许多人会派遣更多的初级部长或官员。

;

;法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙和美国总统乔·拜登选择不出席，他派副总统卡马拉·哈里斯出席。

;

;消息人士称，加拿大总理贾斯汀·特鲁多将派其科学部长弗朗索瓦·菲利普·商鹏飞出席，但第二天可能会以虚拟方式出席。德国总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨 (Olaf Scholz) ;普遍预计;不会出席。

;

;目前预计出席峰会的最著名政治人物是欧盟委员会主席乌苏拉·冯德莱恩和意大利总理乔治亚·梅洛尼

;

;在峰会开始前两天，唐宁街发言人表示：“我们仍然相信，我们已经聚集了人工智能领域合适的世界专家团队——领先的企业，实际上是世界领导人和能够解决这一重要问题的代表。

;

;“这是此类领域的首届人工智能安全峰会。我认为这是一项重大成就，来自世界各地的人们，实际上来自世界各地的领导人，还有人工智能专家，第一次齐聚一堂来研究这些前沿风险。”

;

;苏纳克后来发推文：“周四晚上 X 的人工智能安全峰会后与 @elonmusk 的对话。”消息人士证实，马斯克将亲自出席峰会，两人将面对面进行 X 对话。

;

;今年早些时候，马斯克推出了自己的人工智能业务，名为 X.ai，但他的公司远远落后更成熟的人工智能开发商，如谷歌的 DeepMind 和 OpenAI。

;
;

;;相关：;;人工智能公司必须对其造成的伤害负责，技术“教父”说< /a>;

;
;

;周三出席布莱切利公园的人们将参加为期两天的讨论，讨论业内许多人认为人工智能对人类构成的生存风险。

;

;苏纳克在担心先进人工智能模型的开发没有受到全球监管机构的任何监督后，于今年夏天宣布召开这次会议。一些业内人士认为，如果模型变得比人类聪明得多，他们可能会决定完全消灭人类。

;

;然而，距离峰会开始仅剩几天时间，;出席名单仍在制定中;。;

;苏纳克 ;上周确认;他的官员已邀请中国参加峰会，并表示：“尝试与世界领先的人工智能强国接触是正确的。”

;

;但北京尚未确认据报道，英国官员已决定升级邀请并直接向国家主席习近平发出邀请。

;

;预计习近平不会出席，但英国外交官认为，亲自邀请他将表明他们多么希望中国派出高级官员。

;

;苏纳克的发言人周一表示：“我不会深入探讨此事的来龙去脉。”邀请名单。当然，我认为我们一直在寻求适当水平的代表性……邀请中国很重要，因为他们也是人工智能领域的世界领导者。”

;

;在官员们为峰会做准备时，部长们已经启动了一系列有关人工智能的新举措。

;

;内政大臣 Suella Braverman 与包括 Tik Tok 和 Snapchat 在内的科技公司举行了会议，讨论如何处理人工智能生成的儿童性虐待图像，Braverman 称之为“网络祸害”。科技公司签署了解决这一问题的承诺。

;

;在其他地方，部长们承诺为研究人员额外提供 200 万英镑，为教师开发人工智能工具，并提供 1600 万英镑为诊断人工智能收集更多健康数据。

;

; p>;

;

;但反对特朗普的论点他说，依靠宪法中一项模糊的条款来禁止叛乱。 “这些法律问题非常棘手，”他说，并指出，即使它们被视为可能性不大，它们也提出了重要问题，并且有一条看似合理的成功法律途径。

;

;在支持这一论点的人中支持将特朗普从选票中除名的是弗吉尼亚州参议员蒂姆·凯恩，他是希拉里·克林顿 2016 年的竞选搭档，;上个月告诉美国广播公司;，第14修正案条款中的“语言是特定的”。

;

;“在我看来，那天对国会大厦的袭击是精心设计的在特定时刻出于特定目的，那就是破坏宪法规定的权力和平移交，”他说。

;“所以我认为有一个强有力的论据。 ” 周一，在丹佛的法庭上，一群科罗拉多州选民的律师埃里克·奥尔森 (Eric Olson) 讲述了特朗普在 1 月 6 日袭击事件前的暴力言论，以及他鼓励聚集在距离当时的警察“40 英尺”范围内的人群。 -当他们袭击国会大厦时，迈克·彭斯总统。他说特朗普“召集并组织了暴徒”。

;

;“我们来这里是因为特朗普声称，毕竟他有权再次担任总统，”奥尔森说。 “但我们的宪法，我们国家的共同宪章，规定他不能这样做。”

;

;特朗普的律师辩称，这位前总统从未“参与叛乱”，而只是在行使其言论自由权警告他认为不合法的;选举结果;。法律专家表示，近几个月来，已有数十起援引该修正案的案件被提起，但科罗拉多州和明尼苏达州的案件似乎是最重要的。它们是由两个拥有大量资源的自由派团体提交的，而且所在州对候选人的投票资格提出了明确、迅速的质疑程序。

;

;这意味着科罗拉多州和明尼苏达州的案件正在采取更合法的途径来解决让法院强迫选举官员取消特朗普的资格，这与寻求联邦法官全面裁决特朗普不再有资格担任总统的其他诉讼形成鲜明对比。

;

;华盛顿公民责任与道德组织 (Crew) ）监管机构向科罗拉多州提起诉讼。文件称：“通过煽动对美国宪法秩序的前所未有的攻击，特朗普违反了他的誓言，并根据第十四修正案取消了自己担任公职的资格，包括总统职位。”。

; Tue, 31 Oct 2023 06:22:01 +0800 Sam Bankman-Fried grilled over messy hair as he takes stand in fraud trialhttps://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/oct/30/sbf-testifies-ftx-trial-crypto-day-3
;;2023-10-30T20:03:55Z;
;
;;Sam Bankman-Fried 于 2023 年 3 月 30 日在纽约州纽约市联邦法院外。
;

;曾经的加密货币大亨;Sam Bankman-Fried; 周一再次在他自己的轰动一时的加密审判中作证，他的辩护结束了直接询问，检方开始了尖锐的交叉询问。他周末似乎理了发，正好赶上检察官盘问他那著名的蓬乱头发是否是故意的、反风格的“科技天才”形象的一部分。

;

;周五, Bankman-Fried ;出庭为自己辩护< /a>;，承认他犯了“大错误”，但否认他欺骗了他失败的加密货币交易所 FTX 的任何客户。周一，他因有关 FTX 的许多公开声明和媒体采访以及他的公开和私人声明之间的一些明显对比而受到盘问。

;

;在 Bankman-Fried 返回证人身边的瞬间在主张继续直接审查的情况下，他的律师 Mark Cohen 似乎试图表明这位企业家已尽最大努力让 FTX 变得更好、更安全，并再次将责任归咎于他的前女友兼 Alameda Research 首席执行官 ;卡罗琳·埃里森;，作为;他在盘问期间这样做了;。正如周五所做的那样，科恩和班克曼-弗里德讨论了对冲，特别是他们认为埃里森没有采取能够使阿拉米达免受 2022 年春季加密货币急剧崩盘影响的头寸，这场崩盘危及了对冲基金。

;

;Bankman-Fried 详细介绍了 FTX 遭受数十亿美元客户提款当天的细节，并在短暂考虑了币安的潜在收购后最终破产。在质询过程中，班克曼-弗里德的律师试图将交易所崩溃的责任归咎于币安，币安出售了其在 FTX 加密货币 FTT 中的头寸，实际上对 FTX 发出了不信任票，而班克曼-弗里德则将责任归咎于埃里森未能对冲风险。阿拉米达的财务状况。

;

;作证是一个危险的举动，会让他受到联邦检察官的盘问。班克曼-弗里德的律师结束讯问后，美国助理检察官丹妮尔·沙逊（Danielle Sassoon）对班克曼-弗里德的形象和吸引投资者的情况进行了尖锐的盘问。埃里森作证说，他蓬头垢面的男孩天才外表是一种表演。

;

;今天在法庭上，班克曼-弗里德穿着浅灰色西装和紫色领带，他标志性的疯狂鬃毛现在被修剪成更传统的风格。

;

; p>;

;“班克曼-弗里德先生，您是否同意您知道如何讲一个好故事？”沙逊问道。

;

;班克曼-弗里德转移了注意力，说：“我不知道，这取决于你使用什么衡量标准。”

;

;沙逊盘问他的着装选择，询问他关于一位同事;告诉《纽约时报》;如果他说过剪掉头发会对他产生负面影响，因为“我认为让人们认为我看起来很疯狂很重要，”他说。埃里森同样作证说，班克曼-弗里德精心策划了他平淡无奇的形象。

;

;“我认为我不是那样说的，”班克曼-弗里德说。他此前曾作证称，自己没有剪头发是因为又忙又懒，并非战略决策。

;

;当沙宣问他是否记得告诉另一位要求他穿西装的投资者时，班克曼-弗里德说“T 恤和短裤”是他品牌的一部分，班克曼-弗里德表示他不记得这句话。

;

;除了关注班克曼-弗里德的展示和品牌之外，沙宣还重点关注前者CEO的智慧。班克曼-弗里德的辩护律师试图将他描绘成一个不知所措、超出自己能力范围的年轻人，在试图领导一家快速扩张的企业时“犯了错误”。

;

;“你认为自己是一个聪明人家伙？检察官问道。

;

;“在很多方面，但不是所有方面，”Bankman-Fried 回答道。

;

;“作为 FTX 的首席执行官，您对自己评价很高吗？”她问道。

;

;“我做到了，”他说。

;

;在另一条询问中，沙逊还询问 Bankman-Fried 是否同时拥有 FTX 和 Alameda，针对他的断言：对冲阿拉米达的头寸是埃里森的决定和责任；他表示自己在两家公司都持有大量股份。

;

;沙逊还询问 Bankman-Fried 采取了哪些措施来向潜在客户保证 FTX 是透明和安全的，并询问他计划于 2022 年 12 月在国会作证是否支持监管“只是为了公关”，班克曼-弗里德否认了这一点。他还没来得及作证就被捕了。

;

;“你私下里说过‘操监管机构’之类的话吗？”沙逊问道。

;

;“我说过一次，”班克曼-弗里德承认。

;

;班克曼-弗里德的辩护律师通过他们的提问，把他描绘成一个不知所措的“;数学书呆子;”从未想过会成为富有或出名，当然从来没有打算掠夺数十亿美元。

;

;“我犯了一些小错误和一些大错误，”他周五说道。当被问及 FTX 是否有风险管理部门时，他回答说：“我们当然应该有，但我们没有。”

;

;Bankman-Fried 预计将于上周四开始作证。然而，刘易斯·卡普兰法官在班克曼-弗里德被控七项电汇欺诈和共谋洗钱罪名准备在陪审团面前作证之前召开了证据听证会。卡普兰让陪审团回家，同时考虑班克曼-弗里德作证期间哪些话题可以接受。这位前首席执行官已不认罪。

;

;Bankman-Fried 创立了加密货币交易所 FTX，该交易所因 2022 年底加密行业崩溃而破产。他于 2022 年 12 月在巴哈马被捕并被引渡到美国。如果罪名成立，他将面临数十年的监禁。周四，他在证人席上表示，他相信 FTX 的服务条款允许与加密货币交易所密切相关的对冲基金 Alameda Research 获取 FTX 客户资金。

;

;联邦律师指控 Bankman-Fried “为了自己的目的，从 FTX 挪用和挪用了“数十亿美元”到阿拉米达 - 1 亿美元的政治捐款、名人代言以及价值 4000 万美元的巴哈马顶层公寓，他与埃里森和其他 FTX 高管住在那里。

;

;;埃里森;在审判早些时候作了对他不利的证词，说她作为阿拉米达首席执行官犯下了罪行，而且总是在他的指挥下。 FTX 联合创始人 Gary Wang 作证称，Bankman-Fried 知道资金非法流动，当客户试图提取加密货币时，导致 FTX 出现 80 亿美元的资金缺口。

;;Crowds of people stand looking at a huge pile of flower tributes.
;

;Public tributes to China's former premier Li Keqiang, who died on Friday, are being strictly controlled as the government seeks to prevent a mass outpouring of grief that could lead to social unrest.

;

;Li ;suffered a sudden heart attack ;in Shanghai and died in the early hours of Friday, according to Xinhua news agency.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Li Keqiang obituary;

;
;

;There have been public displays of grief, ;particularly; in his home city of Hefei, in Anhui province, where hundreds of mourners laid flowers for one of their most significant sons.

;

;Social media is awash with tributes to Li, who was once seen as a force for economic liberalisation in the highest echelons of the Chinese Communist party (CCP). But discussion online has been strictly censored to ensure that Li's legacy adheres to the official narrative and does not mention talking points about political or economic reform.

;

;A leaked memo, published by ;China Digital Times;, shows that media outlets have been instructed to “pay particular attention to overly effusive comments” regarding Li's death.

;

;Many of the comments that referenced Li's reputation as an economic reformer were deleted. One comment that was censored from Weibo cited a Li quote from his first year as premier: “Whatever the market can handle, let the market do more of.”

; ;

;Despite being China's premier for a decade, it is not clear whether Li will receive an official memorial in addition to regular funeral arrangements. At the regular foreign ministry press briefing on Friday, spokesperson Mao Ning declined to elaborate on any plans.

;

;Students, seen by CCP elites as the most volatile demographic when it comes to protests, are being instructed to refrain from pubic displays that go beyond the official lines. ;Screenshots; circulating on social media show a message from the Youth League Committee at Hainan University instructing students to “at most” share Li's official obituary. The notice said that any online or offline gatherings were “strictly prohibited”, according to a report in Taiwanese media.

;

;Another notice posted to students at the Guiyang Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics asked them not to make any comments about the “political situation” and to refrain from any public gatherings.

; ;

;When Li became premier in 2013, he was seen as someone who would embrace private enterprise and allow the free market to flourish.但他逐渐被中国领导人习近平排挤，习近平重申了中共对经济各个领域的控制。 To many, Li now represents the path not taken by China's increasingly authoritarian government.

;

;The CCP is particularly fearful about reaction to deaths of senior officials or public figures. The deaths of former premier Zhou Enlai in 1976 and Hu Yaobang, a former CCP general secretary, in 1989, prompted widespread outpourings of grief that morphed into protests.

;

;More recently, the deaths of ;Covid whistleblower Li Wenliang ;in 2020 and people in ;an apartment fire in Xinjiang; in 2022 triggered expressions of public grief – with the latter becoming the “;white paper” protests; that spread across several cities at the end of last year. The CCP leaders are “haunted” by these memories, said Jeffrey Wasserstrom, a professor of Chinese history at the University of California, Irvine.

;

;Many people have flocked to the Weibo page of Li Wenliang to pay their tributes to the more recently departed Li Keqiang. “Today, it seems another truth-teller with the surname Li has departed,” wrote one, in a post archived by China Digital Times.

;

;Li Yuan, a columnist for the New York Times, ;described; the public grief as “the most significant outpouring of emotion since the white paper movement”.

; ;

;Wasserstrom added: “There is definitely a lot of discontent in some quarters about Xi Jinping and little room to express it without taking a big risk … Expressing regret for Li's death provides an opportunity for doing this in at least a veiled way.”

;

;Steve Tsang, director of the SOAS China Institute, also said that “remembering Li fondly is a veiled articulation of unhappiness about Xi”.

;

;With that in mind, Tsang said that there was “no chance” that Xi would allow “anything but a small family affair” for Li.

;

;;A Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton on display
;

;In the end it was the dust that did it for the dinosaurs. At least that is the finding of computer simulations of the aftermath of the asteroid impact that reshaped life on Earth 66m years ago.

;

;The cataclysmic impact in what is now Chicxulub on Mexico's Yucatán peninsula wiped out 75% of species on Earth, including non-avian dinosaurs. But the precise nature of the deadly blow has kept scientists busy for decades, with ;soot-spewing wildfires;, ;volcanic eruptions; and ;vast quantities of sulphur; all considered culprits.

;

;Writing in ;Nature Geoscience;, researchers in Belgium argue that the “exact killing mechanisms” set in train by the impact remain poorly understood and that too little attention has been paid to the role of potentially trillions of tonnes of dust kicked up by the violent event.

;

;Swirling around in the atmosphere for years, soot, sulphur and dust all have the capacity to block out the sun and contribute to a global winter where vegetation fails, with devastating knock-on effects for the animals it supports.

;

;To delve deeper into the role of the different factors, the scientists ran simulations of the ancient climate that took into account measurements of fine particles recovered from a site in North Dakota where a layer of dust generated by the Chicxulub impact settled.

;

;According to the simulations, dust of the size found in Dakota could have remained in the atmosphere for up to 15 years after being blasted into the sky. By blocking out the sun's rays, up to 2,000bn tonnes of it could have shut down photosynthesis for nearly two years and cooled the planet by up to 15C.

;

;Created from pulverised granite and other rock at the impact site, the dust “most likely drove the last mass extinction event through the disruption of photosynthetic activity,” said Cem Berk Senel, a researcher on the study at the Royal Observatory of Belgium in Brussels.

;

;The silicate dust emerged from the simulations as the “most efficient blocker of photosynthesis”, added Philippe Claeys, a geologist and planetary scientist at the Free University of Brussels and co-author of the study. “It renders the atmosphere opaque to sunlight, hampering the plants' photosynthetic process.”

;

;According to the computer models, it would have taken two years for photosynthesis to resume.

;

;Steve Brusatte, a professor of palaeontology and evolution at the University of Edinburgh who was not involved in the study, described the asteroid that killed the dinosaurs as “apocalyptic”.

;

;He said: “It was the largest asteroid to hit the Earth in the last half a billion years, and it detonated with the force of over a billion nuclear bombs put together. But that's not what really killed the dinosaurs and the 75% of other species that died out.

;

;“What really drove their doom was what happened afterwards, as the dust and grime from the asteroid impact went into the atmosphere and blocked out the sun.地球变得黑暗寒冷了几年。 The asteroid didn't kill all the dinosaurs in one go, but it was a more stealthy murderer, which triggered a war of attrition that led three out of every four species to die.”

;Hundreds more watched a live stream of the vigil shown on a huge screen in front of the church. Some held American flags and others had lit candles in cups marked with the names of the dead and injured.

;

;“Remember to seek healing over relief.缓解是暂时的。治愈是永久性的。疼痛是暂时的，”刘易斯顿美南浸信会教堂的牧师加里·布拉格说。 As he spoke, he asked the crowd to welcome their neighbor to the service with the words “I am so glad you are here” and then to ask how they might help them.

;

;The vigil came two days after the suspected gunman, Robert Card, was found dead on Friday evening, of a self-inflicted gunshot wound.

;

;Christian leaders along with a rabbi and an imam spoke at Sunday's event of the pain from the shooting but also the healing process and the resilience of the community of 40,000. There was also a speaker from Lewiston's deaf and hard of hearing community, as four of its members were killed in the shooting while they were at a games night.

;

;Kevin Bohlin, who represented the deaf community, signed his message, which was delivered through an ASL interpreter, about how the tragedy hit close to home for the community. Several in attendance could be seen signing to one another throughout the vigil.

;

;The victims are now gone, he said, “but they are directing us to come together and make a difference in this world.”

;

;The Rev Todd Little from the First United Pentecostal church of Lewiston spoke at the vigil of a diverse community that now has something new in common after the tragedy, talking of “shared brokenness, worry, fear and loss”.

;

;He also vowed that the community was bigger than the tragedy and will emerge not just “Lewiston Strong” but “Lewiston Stronger”.

;

;Meanwhile, Lewiston was slowly reopening.刘易斯顿学校发布了本周的有限时间表，“在我们前进的过程中留有反思的空间”。只有工作人员周一返回，学生周二返回。 The Lewiston city hall planned to reopen on Monday afternoon.

;

;Authorities recovered a multitude of weapons while searching for Card and believe he had legally purchased his guns, including those recovered in his car and near his body, said Jim Ferguson, the special agent in charge of the Boston office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. He declined to discuss any specifics.

;

;Investigators are still searching for a precise motive for the massacre, but have increasingly focused on Card's mental health history.

;

;The state public safety commissioner, Michael Sauschuck, said Card believed “people were talking about him and there may even have been some voices at play”.

;

;Family members of Card told federal investigators that he had recently discussed hearing voices and became more focused on the bowling alley and bar, according to law enforcement officials who spoke with the Associated Press on condition of anonymity in order to discuss details of the investigation.

;

;On Sunday, at Schemengees Bar & Grille, one of the shooting sites, workers in white hazmat suits could be seen methodically cleaning up a staircase. Yellow tape surrounded the site and a small memorial erected nearby featuring colorful balloons, flowers and a poster that read: “Be Strong, Lewiston.”

;

;Leroy Walker, an Auburn city councilor and father of one of the victims, was greeting people at a trick-or-treat event on Sunday, hosted by an organization he leads. He smiled broadly when the children hugged him but he became emotional when he spoke of his son, Joseph, who normally would have joined him at the event.

;

;“It's been a tough few days, trust me. The heart doesn't stop bleeding,” he said.

;

;The deadliest shootings in Maine's history stunned a state of 1.3 million people that has comparatively little violent crime.

;

;Four of the 13 injured remain in hospital.

;

;The Lewiston shootings were the 36th mass killing in the US this year, according to a database maintained by AP and USA Today in partnership with Northeastern University. The database includes every mass killing since 2006 from all weapons in which four or more people, excluding the offender, were killed within a 24-hour time frame.
